elements.definition: Contract represents the underlying to a composed contract. Role of the underlying is derived from the parent. When considered a standalone contract the underlying’s creator takes the liability side.

name: Contract Structure (CTS)
elements.definition: A structure identifying individual or sets of underlying contracts. E.g. for Future (FUTUR), this structure identifies the single underlying contract, for Swap (SWAPS), the FirstLeg and SecondLeg are identified, or for Guarantee (CEG), Collateral (CEC) the structure identifies Covered and Covering contracts.

name: Contract Type (CT)
elements.definition: The ContractType is the most important information. It defines the cash flow generating pattern of a contract. The ContractType information in combination with a given state of the risk factors will produce a deterministic sequence of cash flows which are the basis of any financial analysis.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Principal at Maturity
elements.definition: Lending agreements with full amortization at maturity.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Annuity
elements.definition: Lending agreements with fixed periodic payments consisting of an interest and principal portion. The periodic payments are adjusted for variable rate instruments such that maturity remains fixed.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Negative Amortizer
elements.definition: Lending agreements with fixed periodic payments consisting of an interest and principal portion. Maturity changes for variable rate instruments.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Linear Amortizer
elements.definition: Lending agreements with fixed principal repayment amounts and variable interest payments.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Exotic Linear Amortizer
elements.definition: Lending agreements with exotic repayment schedules.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Call Money
elements.definition: Lonas that are rolled over as long as they are not called. Once called it has to be paid back after the stipulated notice period.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Undefined Maturity Profile
elements.definition: Interest paying cash accounts (current / savings / etc.).

name: Contract Type (CT)
Cash
elements.definition: Represents cash holdings.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Stock
elements.definition: Represents stocks/shares/equity.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Commodity
elements.definition: Represents commodities.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Swap
elements.definition: An agreement of swapping two legs such as fixed against variable or currency 1 against currency 2 etc.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Plain Vanilla Swap
elements.definition: Plain vanilla interest rate swaps.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Foreign Exchange Outright
elements.definition: An agreement of swapping two cash flows in different currencies at a future point in time.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Cap and Floor
elements.definition: An agreement of paying the differential (cap or floor) of a reference rate versus a fixed rate.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Future
elements.definition: An agreement of exchanging an underlying instrument against a fixed price in the future.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Option
elements.definition: Different types of options on buying an underlying instrument at a fixed price in the future.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Credit Enhancement Guarantee
elements.definition: A guarantee / letter of credit by a third party on the scheduled payment obligations of an underlying instrument

name: Contract Type (CT)
Credit Enhancement Collateral
elements.definition: A collateral securing the scheduled payment obligations of an underlying instrument

name: Counterparty Identifier (CPID)
elements.definition: Counterparty Identifier (CPID) identifies the counterparty to the Creator Identifier (CRID) in this contract.Counterparty Identifier (CPID) is ideally the official LEI which can be a firm, a government body, even a single person etc. However, this can also refer to a annonymous group in which case this information is not to be disclosed. Counterparty Identifier (CPID) may also refer to a group taking a joint risk or more generally, Counterparty Identifier (CPID) is the main counterparty, against which the contract has been settled.

name: Currency (CUR)
elements.definition: The currency of the cash flows.

name: Cycle Anchor Date Of Margining (MRANX)
elements.definition: Date from which the margin call date schedule is calculated according to the cycle length. The first margin call event takes place on this anchor.

name: Cycle Of Margining (MRCL)
elements.definition: Defines together with Cycle Anchor Date Of Margining (MRANX) the points where margins can be called.

name: Delinquency Period (DQP)
elements.definition: If real payment happens after scheduled payment date plus DLP, then the counterparty is in technical default. This means that the creditor legally has the right to declare default of the debtor.

name: Delinquency Rate (DQR)
elements.definition: Rate at which Delinquency Payments accrue on Notional Principal (NT) (in addition to the interest rate) during the DelinquencyPeriod.

name: Delivery Settlement (DS)
elements.definition: Indicates whether the contract is settled in cash or physical delivery.In case of physical delivery, the underlying contract and associated (future) cash flows are effectively exchanged. In case of cash settlement, the current market value of the underlying contract determines the cash flow exchanged.

name: Delivery Settlement (DS)
Cash Settlement
elements.definition: The market value of the underlying is settled.

name: Delivery Settlement (DS)
Physical Settlement
elements.definition: The underlying is delivered physically.

name: End Of Month Convention (EOMC)
elements.definition: When computing schedules a special problem arises if an anchor date is at the end of a month and a cycle of monthly or quarterly is applied (yearly in the case of leap years only). How do we have to interpret an anchor date April 30 plus 1M cycles? In case where EOM is selected, it will jump to the 31st of May, then June 30, July 31 and so on. If SM is selected, it will jump to the 30st always with of course an exception in February. This logic applies for all months having 30 or less days and an anchor date at the last day. Month with 31 days will at any rate jump to the last of the month if anchor date is on the last day.

name: End Of Month Convention (EOMC)
Same Day
elements.definition: Schedule times always fall on the schedule anchor date day of the month.

name: End Of Month Convention (EOMC)
End of Month
elements.definition: Schedule times fall on the end of every month if the anchor date represents the last day of the respective month.

name: Exercise Amount (XA)
elements.definition: The amount fixed at Exercise Date for a contingent event/obligation such as a forward condition, optionality etc. The Exercise Amount is fixed at Exercise Date but not settled yet.

name: Exercise Date (XD)
elements.definition: Date of exercising a contingent event/obligation such as a forward condition, optionality etc. The Exercise date marks the observed timestamp of fixing the contingent event and respective payment obligation not necessarily the timestamp of settling the obligation.

name: Futures Price (PFUT)
elements.definition: The price the counterparties agreed upon at which the underlying contract (of a Future (FUTUR)) is exchanged/settled. Quoting is different for different types of underlyings: Fixed Income instruments quoted in percentages, all others are quoted in nominal terms.

name: Grace Period (GRP)
elements.definition: If real payment happens after scheduled payment date plus Grace Period (GRP), then the payment is in delay.

name: Initial Margin (MRIM)
elements.definition: Margin to cover losses which may be incurred as a result of market fluctuations. Upon contract closing or maturity, the Initial Margin (MRIM) is reimbursed.

name: Maintenance Margin Lower Bound (MRMML)
elements.definition: Defines the lower bound of the Maintenance Margin. If Variation Margin (MRVM) falls below Maintenance Margin Lower Bound (MRMML), then capital must be added to reach the original Initial Margin (MRIM).

name: Maintenance Margin Upper Bound (MRMMU)
elements.definition: Defines the upper bound of the Maintenance Margin. If Variation Margin (MRVM) falls above Maintenance Margin Upper Bound (MRMMU), then capital is refunded to reach the original Initial Margin (MRIM).

name: Market Object Code (MOC)
elements.definition: Is pointing to the market value at Status Date (SD) (MarketObject).Unique codes for market objects must be used.

name: Market Value Observed (MVO)
elements.definition: Value as observed in the market at Status Date (SD) per unit. Incase of fixed income instruments it is a fraction.

name: Maturity Date (MD)
elements.definition: Marks the contractual end of the lifecycle of a Contract Type (CT). Generally, date of the last cash flows. This includes normally a principal and an interest payment. Some Maturity Contract Type (CT)s as perpetuals (Perpetual Bonds (PBN)) do not have such a date. For variable amortizing contracts of the Annuity (ANN) Contract Type (CT), this date might be less than the scheduled end of the contract (which is deduced from the periodic payment amount Next Principal Redemption Payment (PRNXT)). In this case it balloons.

name: Non Performing Date (NPD)
elements.definition: The date of the (uncovered) payment event responsible for the current value of the Contract Performance attribute.

name: Price At Purchase Date (PPRD)
elements.definition: Purchase price exchanged at Purchase Date (PRD).  Price At Purchase Date (PPRD) represents a clean price (includes premium/discount but not Accrued Interest (IPAC)).

name: Price At Termination Date (PTD)
elements.definition: Sellingprice exchanged at Price At Termination Date (PTD)  Price At Termination Date (PTD)represents a clean price (includes premium/discount but not Accrued Interest (IPAC).

name: Purchase Date (PRD)
elements.definition: If a contract is bought after initiation (for example a bond on the secondary market) this date has to be set. It refers to the date at which the payment (of Price At Purchase Date (PPRD)) and transfer of the security happens. In other words, Purchase Date (PRD) - if set - takes the role otherwise Initial Exchange Date (IED) has from a cash flow perspective. Note, Counterparty Identifier (CPID) of the Contract Type (CT) is not the counterparty of the transaction!

name: Seniority (SEN)
elements.definition: Refers to the order of repayment in the event of a sale or default of the issuer. .

name: Seniority (SEN)
Senior
elements.definition: Contract represents senior debt.

name: Seniority (SEN)
Junior
elements.definition: Contract represents junior debt.

name: Settlement Currency (CURS)
elements.definition: The currency in which cash flows are settled. This currency can be different from the currency (CUR) in which cash flows or the contract, respectively, is denominated in which case the respective FX-rate applies at settlement time.If no settlement currency is defined the cash flows are settled in the currency in which they are denominated.

name: Settlement Period (STP)
elements.definition: Defines the period from fixing of a contingent event/obligation (Exercise Date) to settlement of the obligation.

name: Status Date (SD)
elements.definition: Status Date (SD) holds the date per which all attributes of the record were updated. This is especially important for the highly dynamic attributes like Accruals, Notional, interest rates in variable instruments etc.

name: Termination Date (TD)
elements.definition: If a contract is sold before Maturity Date (MD) (for example a bond on the secondary market) this date has to be set. It refers to the date at which the payment (of Price At Termination Date (PTD)) and transfer of the security happens. In other words, Termination Date (TD) - if set - takes the role otherwise Maturity Date (MD) has from a cash flow perspective. Note, Counterparty Identifier (CPID) of the Contract Type (CT) is not the counterparty of the transaction!

name: Variation Margin (MRVM)
elements.definition: Variation Margin (MRVM) reflects the accrued but not yet paid margin as per Status Date (SD).  Open traded positions are revalued by the exchange at the end of every trading day using mark-to-market valuation. Often clearing members do not credit or debit their clients daily with Variation Margin (MRVM), but rather use a Maintenance Margin. If the balance falls outside Maintenance Margin Lower Bound (MRMML) (and Maintenance Margin Upper Bound (MRMMU)), then  capital must be added (is refunded) to reach the original margin amount Initial Margin (MRIM). We can also say that Market Value Observed (MVO)+Variation Margin (MRVM) is equal to the reference value as per last margin update.

name: Future - Future (FUTUR)
definition: Keeps track of value changes for any basic Contract Type (CT) as underlying (Principal at Maturity (PAM), Annuity (ANN) etc. but also Foreign Ex-change Outright (FXOUT), Stock (STK), Commodity (COM)). Handles margining calls. Standard interest rate, FX, stock and commodity futures.

name: Business Day Convention (BDC)
elements.definition: Business Day Conventions (BDC's) are linked to a calendar. Calendars have working and non-working days. A Business Day Convention (BDC) value other than N means that cash flows cannot fall on non-working days, they must be shifted to the next business day (following) or the previous on (preceding).These two simple rules get refined twofold:- Following modified (preceding): Same like following (preceding), however if a cash flow gets shifted into a new month, then  it is shifted to preceding (following) business day.- Shift/calculate (SC) and calculate/shift (CS). Accrual, principal, and possibly other calculations are affected by this choice. In the case of SC first the dates are shifted and after the shift cash flows are calculated. In the case of CS it is the other way round.Attention: Does not affect non-cyclical dates such as Purchase Date (PRD), Maturity Date (MD), Termination Date (TD), Capitalization End Date (IPCED) since they can be set to the correct date directly.

name: Business Day Convention (BDC)
No Shift
elements.definition: No shift applied to non-business days.

name: Business Day Convention (BDC)
Shift-Calculate Following
elements.definition: Shift event dates first then calculate accruals etc. Strictly shift to the next following business day.

name: Business Day Convention (BDC)
Shift-Calculate Modified-Following
elements.definition: Shift event dates first then calculate accruals etc. Shift to the next following business day if this falls in the same month. Shift to the most recent preceding business day otherwise.

name: Business Day Convention (BDC)
Calculate-Shift Following
elements.definition: Calculate accruals etc. first then shift event dates. Strictly shift to the next following business day.

name: Business Day Convention (BDC)
Calculate-Shift Modified-Following
elements.definition: Calculate accruals etc. first then shift event dates. Shift to the next following business day if this falls in the same month. Shift to the most recent preceding business day otherwise.

name: Business Day Convention (BDC)
Shift-Calculate Preceding
elements.definition: Shift event dates first then calculate accruals etc. Strictly shift to the most recent preceding business day.

name: Business Day Convention (BDC)
Shift-Calculate Modified-Preceding
elements.definition: Shift event dates first then calculate accruals etc. Shift to the most recent preceding business day if this falls in the same month. Shift to the next following business day otherwise.

name: Business Day Convention (BDC)
Calculate-Shift Preceding
elements.definition: Calculate accruals etc. first then shift event dates. Strictly shift to the most recent preceding business day.

name: Business Day Convention (BDC)
Calculate-Shift Modified-Preceding
elements.definition: Calculate accruals etc. first then shift event dates. Shift to the most recent preceding business day if this falls in the same month. Shift to the next following business day otherwise.

name: Calendar (CLDR)
elements.definition: Calendar defines the non-working days which affect the dates of contract events (CDE's) in combination with End Of Month Convention (EOMC) and Business Day Convention (BDC). Custom calendars can be added as additional enum options.

name: Calendar (CLDR)
No Calendar
elements.definition: No holidays defined

name: Calendar (CLDR)
MondayToFriday
elements.definition: Saturdays and Sundays are holidays

name: Contract Deal Date (CDD)
elements.definition: This date signifies the origination of the contract where an agreement between the customer and the bank has been settled. From this date on, the institution will have a (market) risk position for financial contracts. This is even the case when Initial Exchange Date (IED) is in future.

name: Contract Identifier (CID)
elements.definition: Unique identifier of a contract.  If the system is used on a single firm level, an internal unique ID can be generated. If used on a national or globally level, a globally unique ID is required.

name: Contract Performance (PRF)
elements.definition: Indicates the current contract performance status. Different states of the contract range from performing to default.

name: Contract Performance (PRF)
Performant
elements.definition: Contract is performing according to terms and conditions.

name: Contract Performance (PRF)
Delayed
elements.definition: Contractual payment obligations are delayed according to the Grace Period.

name: Contract Performance (PRF)
Delinquent
elements.definition: Contractual payment obligations are delinquent according to the Delinquency Period.

name: Contract Performance (PRF)
Default
elements.definition: Contract defaulted on payment obligations according to Delinquency Period.

name: Contract Performance (PRF)
Matured
elements.definition: Contract matured.

name: Contract Performance (PRF)
Terminated
elements.definition: Contract has been terminated.

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
elements.definition: Contract Role (CNTRL) defines which position the Creator Identifier (CRID) ( the creator of the contract record ) takes in a contract. For example, whether the contract is an asset or liability, a long or short position for the Creator Identifier (CRID). Most contracts are simple on or off balance sheet positions which are assets, liabilities. Such contracts can also play a secondary role as a collateral. The attribute is highly significant since it determines the direction of all cash flows. The exact meaning is given with each Contract Type (CT) in the ACTUS High Level Specification document.

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
Real Position Asset
elements.definition: Contract creator takes the asset or lender side.

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
Real Position Liability
elements.definition: Contract creator takes the liability or borrower side.

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
Receive First Leg
elements.definition: Contract creator receives the first leg.

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
Pay First Leg
elements.definition: Contract creator pays the first leg.

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
Receive Fix
elements.definition: Contract creator receives the fixed leg.

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
Pay Fix
elements.definition: Contract creator pays the fixed leg.

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
Buyer
elements.definition: Contract creator holds the right to buy the underlying / exercise the option.

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
Seller
elements.definition: Contract creator holds the obligation to sell the underlying / deliver the option.

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
Collateral Position
elements.definition: Contract represents a collateral to an underlying instrument

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
Close out Netting
elements.definition: Contract creator and counterparty agree on netting payment obligations of underlying instruments in case of default.

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
Underlying
elements.definition: Contract represents the underlying to a composed contract. Role of the underlying is derived from the parent.

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
Underlying Plus
elements.definition: Contract represents the underlying to a composed contract. Role of the underlying is derived from the parent. When considered a standalone contract the underlying’s creator takes the asset side.

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
Underlying Minus
elements.definition: Contract represents the underlying to a composed contract. Role of the underlying is derived from the parent. When considered a standalone contract the underlying’s creator takes the liability side.

name: Contract Structure (CTS)
elements.definition: A structure identifying individual or sets of underlying contracts. E.g. for Future (FUTUR), this structure identifies the single underlying contract, for Swap (SWAPS), the FirstLeg and SecondLeg are identified, or for Guarantee (CEG), Collateral (CEC) the structure identifies Covered and Covering contracts.

elements.definition: The ContractType is the most important information. It defines the cash flow generating pattern of a contract. The ContractType information in combination with a given state of the risk factors will produce a deterministic sequence of cash flows which are the basis of any financial analysis.

Principal at Maturity
elements.definition: Lending agreements with full amortization at maturity.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Annuity
elements.definition: Lending agreements with fixed periodic payments consisting of an interest and principal portion. The periodic payments are adjusted for variable rate instruments such that maturity remains fixed.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Negative Amortizer

Linear Amortizer

Exotic Linear Amortizer

name: Contract Type (CT)
Call Money

name: Contract Type (CT)
Undefined Maturity Profile

Cash
elements.definition: Represents cash holdings.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Stock

name: Contract Type (CT)
Commodity
elements.definition: Represents commodities.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Swap

Plain Vanilla Swap

Cap and Floor

Future

name: Contract Type (CT)
Option

name: Contract Type (CT)
Credit Enhancement Guarantee
elements.definition: A guarantee / letter of credit by a third party on the scheduled payment obligations of an underlying instrument

Credit Enhancement Collateral

name: Counterparty Identifier (CPID)
elements.definition: Counterparty Identifier (CPID) identifies the counterparty to the Creator Identifier (CRID) in this contract.Counterparty Identifier (CPID) is ideally the official LEI which can be a firm, a government body, even a single person etc. However, this can also refer to a annonymous group in which case this information is not to be disclosed. Counterparty Identifier (CPID) may also refer to a group taking a joint risk or more generally, Counterparty Identifier (CPID) is the main counterparty, against which the contract has been settled.

name: Currency (CUR)
elements.definition: The currency of the cash flows.

name: Cycle Anchor Date Of Optionality (OPANX)
elements.definition: Used for Basic Maturities (such as Principal at Maturity (PAM), Annuity (ANN) and their Step-up versions) and American and Bermudan style options. - Basic Maturities: Within the group of these Maturities, it indicates the possibility of prepayments. Prepayment features are controlled by Behavior. - American and Bermudan style Options: Begin of exercise period.

name: Cycle Of Optionality (OPCL)
elements.definition: Cycle according to which the option exercise date schedule will be calculated.Cycle Of Optionality (OPCL) can be NULL for American Options or Prepayment Optionality in which case the optionality period starts at Cycle Anchor Date Of Optionality (OPANX) and ends at Option Exercise End Date (OPXED) (for american options) or Maturity Date (MD) (in case of prepayment optionality).The interval will be adjusted yet by End Of Month Convention (EOMC) and Business Day Convention (BDC).

name: Delinquency Period (DQP)
elements.definition: If real payment happens after scheduled payment date plus DLP, then the counterparty is in technical default. This means that the creditor legally has the right to declare default of the debtor.

name: Delinquency Rate (DQR)
elements.definition: Rate at which Delinquency Payments accrue on Notional Principal (NT) (in addition to the interest rate) during the DelinquencyPeriod.

name: Delivery Settlement (DS)
elements.definition: Indicates whether the contract is settled in cash or physical delivery.In case of physical delivery, the underlying contract and associated (future) cash flows are effectively exchanged. In case of cash settlement, the current market value of the underlying contract determines the cash flow exchanged.

name: Delivery Settlement (DS)
Cash Settlement
elements.definition: The market value of the underlying is settled.

name: Delivery Settlement (DS)
Physical Settlement
elements.definition: The underlying is delivered physically.

name: End Of Month Convention (EOMC)
elements.definition: When computing schedules a special problem arises if an anchor date is at the end of a month and a cycle of monthly or quarterly is applied (yearly in the case of leap years only). How do we have to interpret an anchor date April 30 plus 1M cycles? In case where EOM is selected, it will jump to the 31st of May, then June 30, July 31 and so on. If SM is selected, it will jump to the 30st always with of course an exception in February. This logic applies for all months having 30 or less days and an anchor date at the last day. Month with 31 days will at any rate jump to the last of the month if anchor date is on the last day.

name: End Of Month Convention (EOMC)
Same Day
elements.definition: Schedule times always fall on the schedule anchor date day of the month.

name: End Of Month Convention (EOMC)
End of Month
elements.definition: Schedule times fall on the end of every month if the anchor date represents the last day of the respective month.

name: Exercise Amount (XA)
elements.definition: The amount fixed at Exercise Date for a contingent event/obligation such as a forward condition, optionality etc. The Exercise Amount is fixed at Exercise Date but not settled yet.

name: Exercise Date (XD)
elements.definition: Date of exercising a contingent event/obligation such as a forward condition, optionality etc. The Exercise date marks the observed timestamp of fixing the contingent event and respective payment obligation not necessarily the timestamp of settling the obligation.

name: Grace Period (GRP)
elements.definition: If real payment happens after scheduled payment date plus Grace Period (GRP), then the payment is in delay.

name: Market Object Code (MOC)
elements.definition: Is pointing to the market value at Status Date (SD) (MarketObject).Unique codes for market objects must be used.

name: Market Value Observed (MVO)
elements.definition: Value as observed in the market at Status Date (SD) per unit. Incase of fixed income instruments it is a fraction.

name: Maturity Date (MD)
elements.definition: Marks the contractual end of the lifecycle of a Contract Type (CT). Generally, date of the last cash flows. This includes normally a principal and an interest payment. Some Maturity Contract Type (CT)s as perpetuals (Perpetual Bonds (PBN)) do not have such a date. For variable amortizing contracts of the Annuity (ANN) Contract Type (CT), this date might be less than the scheduled end of the contract (which is deduced from the periodic payment amount Next Principal Redemption Payment (PRNXT)). In this case it balloons.

name: Non Performing Date (NPD)
elements.definition: The date of the (uncovered) payment event responsible for the current value of the Contract Performance attribute.

name: Option Exercise End Date (OPXED)
elements.definition: Final exercise date for American and Bermudan options, expiry date for European options.

name: Option Exercise Type (OPXT)
elements.definition: Defines whether the option is European (exercised at a specific date), American (exercised during a span of time) or Bermudan (exercised at certain points during a span of time).

name: Option Exercise Type (OPXT)
European
elements.definition: European-type exercise.

name: Option Exercise Type (OPXT)
Bermudan
elements.definition: Bermudan-type exercise.

name: Option Exercise Type (OPXT)
American
elements.definition: American-type exercise.

name: Option Strike 1 (OPS1)
elements.definition: Strike price of the option. Whether it is a call/put is determined by the attribute Option Type (OPTP), i.e a call or a put (or a combination of call/put).This attribute is used for price related options such as options on bonds, stocks or FX. Interest rate related options (caps/floos) are handled within th RatReset group.

name: Option Strike 2 (OPS2)
elements.definition: Put price in case of call/put.

name: Option Type (OPTP)
elements.definition: Defines whether the option is a call or put or a combination of it. This field has to be seen in combination with Contract Role (CNTRL) where it is defined whether Creator Identifier (CRID) is the buyer or the seller.

name: Option Type (OPTP)
Call
elements.definition: Call option.

name: Option Type (OPTP)
Put
elements.definition: Put option.

name: Option Type (OPTP)
Call-Put
elements.definition: Combination of call and put option.

name: Price At Purchase Date (PPRD)
elements.definition: Purchase price exchanged at Purchase Date (PRD).  Price At Purchase Date (PPRD) represents a clean price (includes premium/discount but not Accrued Interest (IPAC)).

name: Price At Termination Date (PTD)
elements.definition: Sellingprice exchanged at Price At Termination Date (PTD)  Price At Termination Date (PTD)represents a clean price (includes premium/discount but not Accrued Interest (IPAC).

name: Purchase Date (PRD)
elements.definition: If a contract is bought after initiation (for example a bond on the secondary market) this date has to be set. It refers to the date at which the payment (of Price At Purchase Date (PPRD)) and transfer of the security happens. In other words, Purchase Date (PRD) - if set - takes the role otherwise Initial Exchange Date (IED) has from a cash flow perspective. Note, Counterparty Identifier (CPID) of the Contract Type (CT) is not the counterparty of the transaction!

name: Seniority (SEN)
elements.definition: Refers to the order of repayment in the event of a sale or default of the issuer. .

name: Seniority (SEN)
Senior
elements.definition: Contract represents senior debt.

name: Seniority (SEN)
Junior
elements.definition: Contract represents junior debt.

name: Settlement Currency (CURS)
elements.definition: The currency in which cash flows are settled. This currency can be different from the currency (CUR) in which cash flows or the contract, respectively, is denominated in which case the respective FX-rate applies at settlement time.If no settlement currency is defined the cash flows are settled in the currency in which they are denominated.

name: Settlement Period (STP)
elements.definition: Defines the period from fixing of a contingent event/obligation (Exercise Date) to settlement of the obligation.

name: Status Date (SD)
elements.definition: Status Date (SD) holds the date per which all attributes of the record were updated. This is especially important for the highly dynamic attributes like Accruals, Notional, interest rates in variable instruments etc.

name: Termination Date (TD)
elements.definition: If a contract is sold before Maturity Date (MD) (for example a bond on the secondary market) this date has to be set. It refers to the date at which the payment (of Price At Termination Date (PTD)) and transfer of the security happens. In other words, Termination Date (TD) - if set - takes the role otherwise Maturity Date (MD) has from a cash flow perspective. Note, Counterparty Identifier (CPID) of the Contract Type (CT) is not the counterparty of the transaction!

name: Option - Option (OPTNS)
definition: Calculates straight option pay-off for any basic Contract Type (CT) as underlying (Principal at Maturity (PAM), Annuity (ANN) etc.) but also Swap (SWAPS), Foreign Ex-change Outright (FXOUT), Stock (STK) and Commodity (COM). Single, periodic and continuous strike is supported. European, American and Bermudan options with Interest rate, FX and stock futures as underlying instruments.

name: Business Day Convention (BDC)
elements.definition: Business Day Conventions (BDC's) are linked to a calendar. Calendars have working and non-working days. A Business Day Convention (BDC) value other than N means that cash flows cannot fall on non-working days, they must be shifted to the next business day (following) or the previous on (preceding).These two simple rules get refined twofold:- Following modified (preceding): Same like following (preceding), however if a cash flow gets shifted into a new month, then  it is shifted to preceding (following) business day.- Shift/calculate (SC) and calculate/shift (CS). Accrual, principal, and possibly other calculations are affected by this choice. In the case of SC first the dates are shifted and after the shift cash flows are calculated. In the case of CS it is the other way round.Attention: Does not affect non-cyclical dates such as Purchase Date (PRD), Maturity Date (MD), Termination Date (TD), Capitalization End Date (IPCED) since they can be set to the correct date directly.

name: Business Day Convention (BDC)
No Shift
elements.definition: No shift applied to non-business days.

name: Business Day Convention (BDC)
Shift-Calculate Following
elements.definition: Shift event dates first then calculate accruals etc. Strictly shift to the next following business day.

name: Business Day Convention (BDC)
Shift-Calculate Modified-Following
elements.definition: Shift event dates first then calculate accruals etc. Shift to the next following business day if this falls in the same month. Shift to the most recent preceding business day otherwise.

name: Business Day Convention (BDC)
Calculate-Shift Following
elements.definition: Calculate accruals etc. first then shift event dates. Strictly shift to the next following business day.

name: Business Day Convention (BDC)
Calculate-Shift Modified-Following
elements.definition: Calculate accruals etc. first then shift event dates. Shift to the next following business day if this falls in the same month. Shift to the most recent preceding business day otherwise.

name: Business Day Convention (BDC)
Shift-Calculate Preceding
elements.definition: Shift event dates first then calculate accruals etc. Strictly shift to the most recent preceding business day.

name: Business Day Convention (BDC)
Shift-Calculate Modified-Preceding
elements.definition: Shift event dates first then calculate accruals etc. Shift to the most recent preceding business day if this falls in the same month. Shift to the next following business day otherwise.

name: Business Day Convention (BDC)
Calculate-Shift Preceding
elements.definition: Calculate accruals etc. first then shift event dates. Strictly shift to the most recent preceding business day.

name: Business Day Convention (BDC)
Calculate-Shift Modified-Preceding
elements.definition: Calculate accruals etc. first then shift event dates. Shift to the most recent preceding business day if this falls in the same month. Shift to the next following business day otherwise.

name: Calendar (CLDR)
elements.definition: Calendar defines the non-working days which affect the dates of contract events (CDE's) in combination with End Of Month Convention (EOMC) and Business Day Convention (BDC). Custom calendars can be added as additional enum options.

name: Calendar (CLDR)
No Calendar
elements.definition: No holidays defined

name: Calendar (CLDR)
MondayToFriday
elements.definition: Saturdays and Sundays are holidays

name: Contract Deal Date (CDD)
elements.definition: This date signifies the origination of the contract where an agreement between the customer and the bank has been settled. From this date on, the institution will have a (market) risk position for financial contracts. This is even the case when Initial Exchange Date (IED) is in future.

name: Contract Identifier (CID)
elements.definition: Unique identifier of a contract.  If the system is used on a single firm level, an internal unique ID can be generated. If used on a national or globally level, a globally unique ID is required.

name: Contract Performance (PRF)
elements.definition: Indicates the current contract performance status. Different states of the contract range from performing to default.

name: Contract Performance (PRF)
Performant
elements.definition: Contract is performing according to terms and conditions.

name: Contract Performance (PRF)
Delayed
elements.definition: Contractual payment obligations are delayed according to the Grace Period.

name: Contract Performance (PRF)
Delinquent
elements.definition: Contractual payment obligations are delinquent according to the Delinquency Period.

name: Contract Performance (PRF)
Default
elements.definition: Contract defaulted on payment obligations according to Delinquency Period.

name: Contract Performance (PRF)
Matured
elements.definition: Contract matured.

name: Contract Performance (PRF)
Terminated
elements.definition: Contract has been terminated.

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
elements.definition: Contract Role (CNTRL) defines which position the Creator Identifier (CRID) ( the creator of the contract record ) takes in a contract. For example, whether the contract is an asset or liability, a long or short position for the Creator Identifier (CRID). Most contracts are simple on or off balance sheet positions which are assets, liabilities. Such contracts can also play a secondary role as a collateral. The attribute is highly significant since it determines the direction of all cash flows. The exact meaning is given with each Contract Type (CT) in the ACTUS High Level Specification document.

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
Real Position Asset
elements.definition: Contract creator takes the asset or lender side.

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
Real Position Liability
elements.definition: Contract creator takes the liability or borrower side.

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
Receive First Leg
elements.definition: Contract creator receives the first leg.

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
Pay First Leg
elements.definition: Contract creator pays the first leg.

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
Receive Fix
elements.definition: Contract creator receives the fixed leg.

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
Pay Fix
elements.definition: Contract creator pays the fixed leg.

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
Buyer
elements.definition: Contract creator holds the right to buy the underlying / exercise the option.

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
Seller
elements.definition: Contract creator holds the obligation to sell the underlying / deliver the option.

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
Collateral Position
elements.definition: Contract represents a collateral to an underlying instrument

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
Close out Netting
elements.definition: Contract creator and counterparty agree on netting payment obligations of underlying instruments in case of default.

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
Underlying
elements.definition: Contract represents the underlying to a composed contract. Role of the underlying is derived from the parent.

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
Underlying Plus
elements.definition: Contract represents the underlying to a composed contract. Role of the underlying is derived from the parent. When considered a standalone contract the underlying’s creator takes the asset side.

name: Contract Role (CNTRL)
Underlying Minus
elements.definition: Contract represents the underlying to a composed contract. Role of the underlying is derived from the parent. When considered a standalone contract the underlying’s creator takes the liability side.

name: Contract Structure (CTS)
elements.definition: A structure identifying individual or sets of underlying contracts. E.g. for Future (FUTUR), this structure identifies the single underlying contract, for Swap (SWAPS), the FirstLeg and SecondLeg are identified, or for Guarantee (CEG), Collateral (CEC) the structure identifies Covered and Covering contracts.

name: Contract Type (CT)
elements.definition: The ContractType is the most important information. It defines the cash flow generating pattern of a contract. The ContractType information in combination with a given state of the risk factors will produce a deterministic sequence of cash flows which are the basis of any financial analysis.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Principal at Maturity
elements.definition: Lending agreements with full amortization at maturity.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Annuity
elements.definition: Lending agreements with fixed periodic payments consisting of an interest and principal portion. The periodic payments are adjusted for variable rate instruments such that maturity remains fixed.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Negative Amortizer
elements.definition: Lending agreements with fixed periodic payments consisting of an interest and principal portion. Maturity changes for variable rate instruments.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Linear Amortizer
elements.definition: Lending agreements with fixed principal repayment amounts and variable interest payments.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Exotic Linear Amortizer
elements.definition: Lending agreements with exotic repayment schedules.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Call Money
elements.definition: Lonas that are rolled over as long as they are not called. Once called it has to be paid back after the stipulated notice period.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Undefined Maturity Profile
elements.definition: Interest paying cash accounts (current / savings / etc.).

name: Contract Type (CT)
Cash
elements.definition: Represents cash holdings.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Stock
elements.definition: Represents stocks/shares/equity.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Commodity
elements.definition: Represents commodities.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Swap
elements.definition: An agreement of swapping two legs such as fixed against variable or currency 1 against currency 2 etc.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Plain Vanilla Swap
elements.definition: Plain vanilla interest rate swaps.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Foreign Exchange Outright
elements.definition: An agreement of swapping two cash flows in different currencies at a future point in time.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Cap and Floor
elements.definition: An agreement of paying the differential (cap or floor) of a reference rate versus a fixed rate.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Future
elements.definition: An agreement of exchanging an underlying instrument against a fixed price in the future.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Option
elements.definition: Different types of options on buying an underlying instrument at a fixed price in the future.

name: Contract Type (CT)
Credit Enhancement Guarantee
elements.definition: A guarantee / letter of credit by a third party on the scheduled payment obligations of an underlying instrument

name: Contract Type (CT)
Credit Enhancement Collateral
elements.definition: A collateral securing the scheduled payment obligations of an underlying instrument

name: Counterparty Identifier (CPID)
elements.definition: Counterparty Identifier (CPID) identifies the counterparty to the Creator Identifier (CRID) in this contract.Counterparty Identifier (CPID) is ideally the official LEI which can be a firm, a government body, even a single person etc. However, this can also refer to a annonymous group in which case this information is not to be disclosed. Counterparty Identifier (CPID) may also refer to a group taking a joint risk or more generally, Counterparty Identifier (CPID) is the main counterparty, against which the contract has been settled.

name: Currency (CUR)
elements.definition: The currency of the cash flows.

name: Cycle Anchor Date Of Optionality (OPANX)
elements.definition: Used for Basic Maturities (such as Principal at Maturity (PAM), Annuity (ANN) and their Step-up versions) and American and Bermudan style options. - Basic Maturities: Within the group of these Maturities, it indicates the possibility of prepayments. Prepayment features are controlled by Behavior. - American and Bermudan style Options: Begin of exercise period.

name: Cycle Of Optionality (OPCL)
elements.definition: Cycle according to which the option exercise date schedule will be calculated.Cycle Of Optionality (OPCL) can be NULL for American Options or Prepayment Optionality in which case the optionality period starts at Cycle Anchor Date Of Optionality (OPANX) and ends at Option Exercise End Date (OPXED) (for american options) or Maturity Date (MD) (in case of prepayment optionality).The interval will be adjusted yet by End Of Month Convention (EOMC) and Business Day Convention (BDC).

name: Delinquency Period (DQP)
elements.definition: If real payment happens after scheduled payment date plus DLP, then the counterparty is in technical default. This means that the creditor legally has the right to declare default of the debtor.

name: Delinquency Rate (DQR)
elements.definition: Rate at which Delinquency Payments accrue on Notional Principal (NT) (in addition to the interest rate) during the DelinquencyPeriod.

name: Delivery Settlement (DS)
elements.definition: Indicates whether the contract is settled in cash or physical delivery.In case of physical delivery, the underlying contract and associated (future) cash flows are effectively exchanged. In case of cash settlement, the current market value of the underlying contract determines the cash flow exchanged.

name: Delivery Settlement (DS)
Cash Settlement
elements.definition: The market value of the underlying is settled.

name: Delivery Settlement (DS)
Physical Settlement
elements.definition: The underlying is delivered physically.

name: End Of Month Convention (EOMC)
elements.definition: When computing schedules a special problem arises if an anchor date is at the end of a month and a cycle of monthly or quarterly is applied (yearly in the case of leap years only). How do we have to interpret an anchor date April 30 plus 1M cycles? In case where EOM is selected, it will jump to the 31st of May, then June 30, July 31 and so on. If SM is selected, it will jump to the 30st always with of course an exception in February. This logic applies for all months having 30 or less days and an anchor date at the last day. Month with 31 days will at any rate jump to the last of the month if anchor date is on the last day.

name: End Of Month Convention (EOMC)
Same Day
elements.definition: Schedule times always fall on the schedule anchor date day of the month.

name: End Of Month Convention (EOMC)
End of Month
elements.definition: Schedule times fall on the end of every month if the anchor date represents the last day of the respective month.

name: Exercise Amount (XA)
elements.definition: The amount fixed at Exercise Date for a contingent event/obligation such as a forward condition, optionality etc. The Exercise Amount is fixed at Exercise Date but not settled yet.

name: Exercise Date (XD)
elements.definition: Date of exercising a contingent event/obligation such as a forward condition, optionality etc. The Exercise date marks the observed timestamp of fixing the contingent event and respective payment obligation not necessarily the timestamp of settling the obligation.

name: Grace Period (GRP)
elements.definition: If real payment happens after scheduled payment date plus Grace Period (GRP), then the payment is in delay.

name: Market Object Code (MOC)
elements.definition: Is pointing to the market value at Status Date (SD) (MarketObject).Unique codes for market objects must be used.

name: Market Value Observed (MVO)
elements.definition: Value as observed in the market at Status Date (SD) per unit. Incase of fixed income instruments it is a fraction.

name: Maturity Date (MD)
elements.definition: Marks the contractual end of the lifecycle of a Contract Type (CT). Generally, date of the last cash flows. This includes normally a principal and an interest payment. Some Maturity Contract Type (CT)s as perpetuals (Perpetual Bonds (PBN)) do not have such a date. For variable amortizing contracts of the Annuity (ANN) Contract Type (CT), this date might be less than the scheduled end of the contract (which is deduced from the periodic payment amount Next Principal Redemption Payment (PRNXT)). In this case it balloons.

name: Non Performing Date (NPD)
elements.definition: The date of the (uncovered) payment event responsible for the current value of the Contract Performance attribute.

name: Option Exercise End Date (OPXED)
elements.definition: Final exercise date for American and Bermudan options, expiry date for European options.

name: Option Exercise Type (OPXT)
elements.definition: Defines whether the option is European (exercised at a specific date), American (exercised during a span of time) or Bermudan (exercised at certain points during a span of time).

name: Option Exercise Type (OPXT)
European
elements.definition: European-type exercise.

name: Option Exercise Type (OPXT)
Bermudan
elements.definition: Bermudan-type exercise.

name: Option Exercise Type (OPXT)
American
elements.definition: American-type exercise.

name: Option Strike 1 (OPS1)
elements.definition: Strike price of the option. Whether it is a call/put is determined by the attribute Option Type (OPTP), i.e a call or a put (or a combination of call/put).This attribute is used for price related options such as options on bonds, stocks or FX. Interest rate related options (caps/floos) are handled within th RatReset group.

name: Option Strike 2 (OPS2)
elements.definition: Put price in case of call/put.

name: Option Type (OPTP)
elements.definition: Defines whether the option is a call or put or a combination of it. This field has to be seen in combination with Contract Role (CNTRL) where it is defined whether Creator Identifier (CRID) is the buyer or the seller.

name: Option Type (OPTP)
Call
elements.definition: Call option.

name: Option Type (OPTP)
Put
elements.definition: Put option.

name: Option Type (OPTP)
Call-Put
elements.definition: Combination of call and put option.

name: Price At Purchase Date (PPRD)
elements.definition: Purchase price exchanged at Purchase Date (PRD).  Price At Purchase Date (PPRD) represents a clean price (includes premium/discount but not Accrued Interest (IPAC)).

name: Price At Termination Date (PTD)
elements.definition: Sellingprice exchanged at Price At Termination Date (PTD)  Price At Termination Date (PTD)represents a clean price (includes premium/discount but not Accrued Interest (IPAC).

name: Purchase Date (PRD)
elements.definition: If a contract is bought after initiation (for example a bond on the secondary market) this date has to be set. It refers to the date at which the payment (of Price At Purchase Date (PPRD)) and transfer of the security happens. In other words, Purchase Date (PRD) - if set - takes the role otherwise Initial Exchange Date (IED) has from a cash flow perspective. Note, Counterparty Identifier (CPID) of the Contract Type (CT) is not the counterparty of the transaction!

name: Seniority (SEN)
elements.definition: Refers to the order of repayment in the event of a sale or default of the issuer. .

name: Seniority (SEN)
Senior
elements.definition: Contract represents senior debt.

name: Seniority (SEN)
Junior
elements.definition: Contract represents junior debt.

name: Settlement Currency (CURS)
elements.definition: The currency in which cash flows are settled. This currency can be different from the currency (CUR) in which cash flows or the contract, respectively, is denominated in which case the respective FX-rate applies at settlement time.If no settlement currency is defined the cash flows are settled in the currency in which they are denominated.

name: Settlement Period (STP)
elements.definition: Defines the period from fixing of a contingent event/obligation (Exercise Date) to settlement of the obligation.

name: Status Date (SD)
elements.definition: Status Date (SD) holds the date per which all attributes of the record were updated. This is especially important for the highly dynamic attributes like Accruals, Notional, interest rates in variable instruments etc.

name: Termination Date (TD)
elements.definition: If a contract is sold before Maturity Date (MD) (for example a bond on the secondary market) this date has to be set. It refers to the date at which the payment (of Price At Termination Date (PTD)) and transfer of the security happens. In other words, Termination Date (TD) - if set - takes the role otherwise Maturity Date (MD) has from a cash flow perspective. Note, Counterparty Identifier (CPID) of the Contract Type (CT) is not the counterparty of the transaction!

name: Warrant - Option (OPTNS)
definition: Calculates straight option pay-off for any basic Contract Type (CT) as underlying (Principal at Maturity (PAM), Annuity (ANN) etc.) but also Swap (SWAPS), Foreign Ex-change Outright (FXOUT), Stock (STK) and Commodity (COM). Single, periodic and continuous strike is supported. European, American and Bermudan options with Interest rate, FX and stock futures as underlying instruments.

name: SecurityIDSource
elements.definition: Identifies class or source of the SecurityID(48) value. - Conditionally required when SecurityID(48) is specified.

name: SecurityIDSource
CUSIP
elements.definition: CUSIP

name: SecurityIDSource
SEDOL
elements.definition: SEDOL

name: SecurityIDSource
QUIK
elements.definition: QUIK

name: SecurityIDSource
ISINNumber
elements.definition: ISIN

name: SecurityIDSource
ExchangeSymbol
elements.definition: Exchange symbol

name: SecurityIDSource
ConsolidatedTapeAssociation
elements.definition: Consolidated Tape Association (CTA) Symbol (SIAC CTS/CQS line format)

name: SecurityIDSource
BloombergSymbol
elements.definition: Bloomberg Symbol

name: SecurityIDSource
Wertpapier
elements.definition: Wertpapier

name: SecurityIDSource
Dutch
elements.definition: Dutch

name: SecurityIDSource
Valoren
elements.definition: Valoren

name: SecurityIDSource
Sicovam
elements.definition: Sicovam

name: SecurityIDSource
Belgian
elements.definition: Belgian

name: SecurityIDSource
Common
elements.definition: "Common" (Clearstream and Euroclear)

name: SecurityIDSource
ClearingHouse
elements.definition: Clearing house / Clearing organization

name: SecurityIDSource
LetterOfCredit
elements.definition: Letter of credit

name: SecurityIDSource
MarketplaceAssignedIdentifier
elements.definition: Marketplace-assigned Identifier

name: SecurityIDSource
FinancialInstrumentGlobalIdentifier
elements.definition: Financial Instrument Global Identifier - An Object Management Group (OMG) standard. Also referred to as FIGI. Formerly known as "Bloomberg Open Symbology BBGID".

name: SecurityIDSource
FidessaInstrumentMnemonic
elements.definition: Fidessa Instrument Mnemonic (FIM)

name: SecurityID
elements.definition: Security identifier value of SecurityIDSource (22) type (e.g. CUSIP, SEDOL, ISIN, etc). Requires SecurityIDSource. - Takes precedence in identifying security to counterparty over SecurityAltID block. Requires SecurityIDSource if specified.

name: Symbol
elements.definition: Ticker symbol. Common, "human understood" representation of the security. SecurityID (48) value can be specified if no symbol exists (e.g. non-exchange traded Collective Investment Vehicles)Use "[N/A]" for products which do not have a symbol. - Common, "human understood" representation of the security. name: SecurityExchange
elements.definition: Market used to help identify a security.Valid values:See "Appendix 6-C" - Can be used to identify the security.

name: CouponRate
elements.definition: The rate of interest that, when multiplied by the principal, par value, or face value of a bond, provides the currency amount of the periodic interest payment. The coupon is always cited, along with maturity, in any quotation of a bond's price. - For Fixed Income.

name: CouponPaymentDate
elements.definition: Date interest is to be paid. Used in identifying Corporate Bond issues.(Note tag # was reserved in FIX 4.1, added in FIX 4.3)(prior to FIX 4.4 field was of type UTCDate) - Date interest is to be paid. Used in identifying Corporate Bond issues.

name: IssueDate
elements.definition: The date on which a bond or stock offering is issued. It may or may not be the same as the effective date ("Dated Date") or the date on which interest begins to accrue ("Interest Accrual Date")(Note tag # was reserved in FIX 4.1, added in FIX 4.3)(prior to FIX 4.4 field was of type UTCDate) - Date instrument was issued. For Fixed Income IOIs for new issues, specifies the issue date.

name: Factor
elements.definition: For Fixed Income: Amorization Factor for deriving Current face from Original face for ABS or MBS securities, note the fraction may be greater than, equal to or less than . In TIPS securities this is the Inflation index.Qty * Factor * Price = Gross Trade AmountFor Derivatives: Contract Value Factor by which price must be adjusted to determine the true nominal value of one futures/options contract.(Qty * Price) * Factor = Nominal Value(Note tag # was reserved in FIX 4.1, added in FIX 4.3) - For Fixed Income: Amortization Factor for deriving Current face from Original face for ABS or MBS securities, note the fraction may be greater than, equal to or less than 1. In TIPS securities this is the Inflation index.Qty * Factor * Price = Gross Trade AmountFor Derivatives: Contract Value Factor by which price must be adjusted to determine the true nominal value of one futures/options contract.(Qty * Price) * Factor = Nominal Value

name: CFICode
elements.definition: Indicates the type of security using ISO 10962 standard, Classification of Financial Instruments (CFI code) values. ISO 10962 is maintained by ANNA (Association of National Numbering Agencies) acting as Registration Authority. See "Appendix 6-B FIX Fields Based Upon Other Standards". See also the Product (460) and SecurityType (167) fields. It is recommended that CFICode be used instead of SecurityType (167) for non-Fixed Income instruments.A subset of possible values applicable to FIX usage are identified in "Appendix 6-D CFICode Usage - ISO 10962 Classification of Financial Instruments (CFI code)" - Indicates the type of security using ISO 10962 standard, Classification of Financial Instruments (CFI code) values. It is recommended that CFICode be used instead of SecurityType for non-Fixed Income instruments.

name: CountryOfIssue
elements.definition: ISO Country code of instrument issue (e.g. the country portion typically used in ISIN). Can be used in conjunction with non-ISIN SecurityID (48) (e.g. CUSIP for Municipal Bonds without ISIN) to provide uniqueness. - ISO Country code of instrument issue (e.g. the country portion typically used in ISIN). Can be used in conjunction with non-ISIN SecurityID (e.g. CUSIP for Municipal Bonds without ISIN) to provide uniqueness.

name: StateOrProvinceOfIssue
elements.definition: A two-character state or province abbreviation. - A two-character state or province abbreviation.

name: LocaleOfIssue
elements.definition: Identifies the locale or region of issue. - For Municipal Security Issuers other than state or province. Refer to http://www.atmos.albany.edu/cgi/stagrep-cgi. Reference the IATA city codes for values. Note IATA (International Air Transport Association) maintains the codes at www.iata.org. For other securities the value may be a region of the issuer, e.g. North America. - The three-character IATA code for a locale (e.g. airport code for Municipal Bonds).

name: MaturityDate
elements.definition: Date of maturity. - Specifies date of maturity (a full date). Note that standardized derivatives which are typically only referenced by month and year (e.g. S&P futures) may use MaturityMonthYear(200) and/or this field.When using MaturityMonthYear(200), it is recommended that markets and sell sides report the MaturityDate(541) on all outbound messages as a means of data enrichment.For NDFs this represents the fixing date of the contract.

name: InstrRegistry
elements.definition: Values may include BIC for the depository or custodian who maintain ownership records, the ISO country code for the location of the record, or the value "ZZ" to specify physical ownership of the security (e.g. stock certificate). - The location at which records of ownership are maintained for this instrument, and at which ownership changes must be recorded. Can be used in conjunction with ISIN to address ISIN uniqueness issues.

name: SecuritySubType
elements.definition: Sub-type qualification/identification of the SecurityType. As an example for SecurityType(167)="REPO", the SecuritySubType="General Collateral" can be used to further specify the type of REPO.If SecuritySubType is used, then SecurityType is required.For SecurityType="MLEG" a name of the option or futures strategy name can be specified, such as "Calendar", "Vertical", "Butterfly".For SecurityType(167)="OPT" the subclassification can be specified, such as "Asian".For SecurityType(167)="SWAPTION" a value of "Straddle" is used to identify a straddle swaption.In the context of EU SFTR reporting use the appropriate 4-character code noted in the regulations - "GENE" for general collateral or "SPEC" for specific collateral (without quote marks). - Sub-type qualification/identification of the SecurityType (e.g. for SecurityType="MLEG"). If specified, SecurityType is required.

name: DatedDate
elements.definition: The effective date of a new securities issue determined by its underwriters. Often but not always the same as the Issue Date and the Interest Accrual Date - If different from IssueDate

name: InterestAccrualDate
elements.definition: The start date used for calculating accrued interest on debt instruments which are being sold between interest payment dates. Often but not always the same as the Issue Date and the Dated Date - If different from IssueDate and DatedDate

name: CFICode
elements.definition: Indicates the type of security using ISO 10962 standard, Classification of Financial Instruments (CFI code) values. ISO 10962 is maintained by ANNA (Association of National Numbering Agencies) acting as Registration Authority. See "Appendix 6-B FIX Fields Based Upon Other Standards". See also the Product (460) and SecurityType (167) fields. It is recommended that CFICode be used instead of SecurityType (167) for non-Fixed Income instruments.A subset of possible values applicable to FIX usage are identified in "Appendix 6-D CFICode Usage - ISO 10962 Classification of Financial Instruments (CFI code)" - Indicates the type of security using ISO 10962 standard, Classification of Financial Instruments (CFI code) values. It is recommended that CFICode be used instead of SecurityType for non-Fixed Income instruments.

name: AssetType

name: SecurityType
elements.definition: Indicates type of security. Security type enumerations are grouped by Product(460) field value. NOTE: Additional values may be used by mutual agreement of the counterparties. - It is recommended that CFICode be used instead of SecurityType for non-Fixed Income instruments.Required for Fixed Income. name: MaturityMonthYear
elements.definition: Can be used with standardized derivatives vs. the MaturityDate (54) field. Month and Year of the maturity (used for standardized futures and options).Format:YYYYMM (e.g. 199903)YYYYMMDD (e.g. 20030323)YYYYMMwN (e.g. 200303w) for weekA specific date or can be appended to the MaturityMonthYear. For instance, if multiple standard products exist that mature in the same Year and Month, but actually mature at a different time, a value can be appended, such as "w" or "w2" to indicate week as opposed to week 2 expiration. Likewise, the date (0-3) can be appended to indicate a specific expiration (maturity date). - Specifies the month and year of maturity. Applicable for standardized derivatives which are typically only referenced by month and year (e.g. S&P futures). Note MaturityDate (a full date) can also be specified.

name: SecurityExchange
elements.definition: Market used to help identify a security.Valid values:See "Appendix 6-C" - Can be used to identify the security.

name: IssueDate
elements.definition: The date on which a bond or stock offering is issued. It may or may not be the same as the effective date ("Dated Date") or the date on which interest begins to accrue ("Interest Accrual Date")(Note tag # was reserved in FIX 4.1, added in FIX 4.3)(prior to FIX 4.4 field was of type UTCDate) - Date instrument was issued. For Fixed Income IOIs for new issues, specifies the issue date.

name: ContractMultiplier
elements.definition: Specifies the ratio or multiply factor to convert from "nominal" units (e.g. contracts) to total units (e.g. shares) (e.g. 1.0, 100, 1000, etc). Applicable For Fixed Income, Convertible Bonds, Derivatives, etc. - In general quantities for all classes should be expressed in the basic unit of the instrument, e.g. shares for equities, nominal or par amount for bonds, currency for foreign exchange. When quantity is expressed in contracts, e.g. financing transactions and bond trade reporting, ContractMultiplier(231) should contain the number of units in one contract and can be omitted if the multiplier is the default amount for the instrument, i.e. 1,000 par of bonds, 1,000,000 par for financing transactions. - For Fixed Income, Convertible Bonds, Derivatives, etc. Note: If used, quantities should be expressed in the "nominal" (e.g. contracts vs. shares) amount.

name: CFICode
elements.definition: Indicates the type of security using ISO 10962 standard, Classification of Financial Instruments (CFI code) values. ISO 10962 is maintained by ANNA (Association of National Numbering Agencies) acting as Registration Authority. See "Appendix 6-B FIX Fields Based Upon Other Standards". See also the Product (460) and SecurityType (167) fields. It is recommended that CFICode be used instead of SecurityType (167) for non-Fixed Income instruments.A subset of possible values applicable to FIX usage are identified in "Appendix 6-D CFICode Usage - ISO 10962 Classification of Financial Instruments (CFI code)" - Indicates the type of security using ISO 10962 standard, Classification of Financial Instruments (CFI code) values. It is recommended that CFICode be used instead of SecurityType for non-Fixed Income instruments.

name: MaturityDate
elements.definition: Date of maturity. - Specifies date of maturity (a full date). Note that standardized derivatives which are typically only referenced by month and year (e.g. S&P futures) may use MaturityMonthYear(200) and/or this field.When using MaturityMonthYear(200), it is recommended that markets and sell sides report the MaturityDate(541) on all outbound messages as a means of data enrichment.For NDFs this represents the fixing date of the contract.

name: ContractSettlMonth
elements.definition: Specifies when the contract (i.e. MBS/TBA) will settle. - Must be present for MBS/TBA

name: SecuritySubType
elements.definition: Sub-type qualification/identification of the SecurityType. As an example for SecurityType(167)="REPO", the SecuritySubType="General Collateral" can be used to further specify the type of REPO.If SecuritySubType is used, then SecurityType is required.For SecurityType="MLEG" a name of the option or futures strategy name can be specified, such as "Calendar", "Vertical", "Butterfly".For SecurityType(167)="OPT" the subclassification can be specified, such as "Asian".For SecurityType(167)="SWAPTION" a value of "Straddle" is used to identify a straddle swaption.In the context of EU SFTR reporting use the appropriate 4-character code noted in the regulations - "GENE" for general collateral or "SPEC" for specific collateral (without quote marks). - Sub-type qualification/identification of the SecurityType (e.g. for SecurityType="MLEG"). If specified, SecurityType is required.

name: MaturityMonthYear
elements.definition: Can be used with standardized derivatives vs. the MaturityDate (54) field. Month and Year of the maturity (used for standardized futures and options).Format:YYYYMM (e.g. 199903)YYYYMMDD (e.g. 20030323)YYYYMMwN (e.g. 200303w) for weekA specific date or can be appended to the MaturityMonthYear. For instance, if multiple standard products exist that mature in the same Year and Month, but actually mature at a different time, a value can be appended, such as "w" or "w2" to indicate week as opposed to week 2 expiration. Likewise, the date (0-3) can be appended to indicate a specific expiration (maturity date). - Specifies the month and year of maturity. Applicable for standardized derivatives which are typically only referenced by month and year (e.g. S&P futures). Note MaturityDate (a full date) can also be specified.

name: PutOrCall
elements.definition: Indicates whether an option contract is a put, call, chooser or undetermined. - Used to express option right

name: StrikePrice
elements.definition: Strike Price for an Option. - Used for derivatives, such as options and covered warrants

name: OptAttribute
elements.definition: Provided to support versioning of option contracts as a result of corporate actions or events. Use of this field is defined by counterparty agreement or market conventions. - Used for derivatives, such as options and covered warrants to indicate a versioning of the contract when required due to corporate actions to the underlying. Should not be used to indicate type of option - use the CFICode[461] for this purpose.

name: SecurityExchange
elements.definition: Market used to help identify a security.Valid values:See "Appendix 6-C" - Can be used to identify the security.

name: IssueDate
elements.definition: The date on which a bond or stock offering is issued. It may or may not be the same as the effective date ("Dated Date") or the date on which interest begins to accrue ("Interest Accrual Date")(Note tag # was reserved in FIX 4.1, added in FIX 4.3)(prior to FIX 4.4 field was of type UTCDate) - Date instrument was issued. For Fixed Income IOIs for new issues, specifies the issue date.

name: ContractMultiplier
elements.definition: Specifies the ratio or multiply factor to convert from "nominal" units (e.g. contracts) to total units (e.g. shares) (e.g. 1.0, 100, 1000, etc). Applicable For Fixed Income, Convertible Bonds, Derivatives, etc. - In general quantities for all classes should be expressed in the basic unit of the instrument, e.g. shares for equities, nominal or par amount for bonds, currency for foreign exchange. When quantity is expressed in contracts, e.g. financing transactions and bond trade reporting, ContractMultiplier(231) should contain the number of units in one contract and can be omitted if the multiplier is the default amount for the instrument, i.e. 1,000 par of bonds, 1,000,000 par for financing transactions. - For Fixed Income, Convertible Bonds, Derivatives, etc. Note: If used, quantities should be expressed in the "nominal" (e.g. contracts vs. shares) amount.

name: CFICode
elements.definition: Indicates the type of security using ISO 10962 standard, Classification of Financial Instruments (CFI code) values. ISO 10962 is maintained by ANNA (Association of National Numbering Agencies) acting as Registration Authority. See "Appendix 6-B FIX Fields Based Upon Other Standards". See also the Product (460) and SecurityType (167) fields. It is recommended that CFICode be used instead of SecurityType (167) for non-Fixed Income instruments.A subset of possible values applicable to FIX usage are identified in "Appendix 6-D CFICode Usage - ISO 10962 Classification of Financial Instruments (CFI code)" - Indicates the type of security using ISO 10962 standard, Classification of Financial Instruments (CFI code) values. It is recommended that CFICode be used instead of SecurityType for non-Fixed Income instruments.

name: MaturityDate
elements.definition: Date of maturity. - Specifies date of maturity (a full date). Note that standardized derivatives which are typically only referenced by month and year (e.g. S&P futures) may use MaturityMonthYear(200) and/or this field.When using MaturityMonthYear(200), it is recommended that markets and sell sides report the MaturityDate(541) on all outbound messages as a means of data enrichment.For NDFs this represents the fixing date of the contract.

name: SecuritySubType
elements.definition: Sub-type qualification/identification of the SecurityType. As an example for SecurityType(167)="REPO", the SecuritySubType="General Collateral" can be used to further specify the type of REPO.If SecuritySubType is used, then SecurityType is required.For SecurityType="MLEG" a name of the option or futures strategy name can be specified, such as "Calendar", "Vertical", "Butterfly".For SecurityType(167)="OPT" the subclassification can be specified, such as "Asian".For SecurityType(167)="SWAPTION" a value of "Straddle" is used to identify a straddle swaption.In the context of EU SFTR reporting use the appropriate 4-character code noted in the regulations - "GENE" for general collateral or "SPEC" for specific collateral (without quote marks). - Sub-type qualification/identification of the SecurityType (e.g. for SecurityType="MLEG"). If specified, SecurityType is required.

name: StrikeCurrency
elements.definition: Currency in which the StrikePrice is denominated. - Used for derivatives

name: SettleOnOpenFlag
elements.definition: Indicator to determine if instrument is settle on open - Indicator to determine if Instrument is Settle on Open.

name: StrikeMultiplier
elements.definition: Used for derivatives. Multiplier applied to the strike price for the purpose of calculating the settlement value. - Used for derivatives. Multiplier applied to the strike price for the purpose of calculating the settlement value.

name: StrikeValue
elements.definition: Used for derivatives. The number of shares/units for the financial instrument involved in the option trade. - Used for derivatives. The number of shares/units for the financial instrument involved in the option trade.

name: SettlMethod
elements.definition: Settlement method for a contract or instrument. Additional values may be used with bilateral agreement. - Conditionally required if SettlSubMethod(2579) is specified.

name: SettlMethod
CashSettlementRequired
elements.definition: Cash settlement required

name: SettlMethod
PhysicalSettlementRequired
elements.definition: Physical settlement required

name: SettlMethod
Election
elements.definition: Election at exercise - The settlement method will be elected at the time of contract exercise.

name: ExerciseStyle
elements.definition: Type of exercise of a derivatives security - Type of exercise of a derivatives security

name: OptPayoutAmount
elements.definition: Cash amount indicating the pay out associated with an option. For binary options this is a fixed amount. - Conditionally required if OptPayoutType(1482) = 3 (Binary).

name: FlexibleIndicator
elements.definition: Used to indicate a derivatives security that can be defined using flexible terms. The terms commonly permitted to be defined by market participants are expiration date and strike price. FlexibleIndicator is an alternative CFICode(461) Standard/Non-standard attribute. - Used to indicate if a security has been defined as flexible according to "non-standard" means. Analog to CFICode Standard/Non-standard indicator

name: MaturityMonthYear
elements.definition: Can be used with standardized derivatives vs. the MaturityDate (54) field. Month and Year of the maturity (used for standardized futures and options).Format:YYYYMM (e.g. 199903)YYYYMMDD (e.g. 20030323)YYYYMMwN (e.g. 200303w) for weekA specific date or can be appended to the MaturityMonthYear. For instance, if multiple standard products exist that mature in the same Year and Month, but actually mature at a different time, a value can be appended, such as "w" or "w2" to indicate week as opposed to week 2 expiration. Likewise, the date (0-3) can be appended to indicate a specific expiration (maturity date). - Specifies the month and year of maturity. Applicable for standardized derivatives which are typically only referenced by month and year (e.g. S&P futures). Note MaturityDate (a full date) can also be specified.

name: OptAttribute
elements.definition: Provided to support versioning of option contracts as a result of corporate actions or events. Use of this field is defined by counterparty agreement or market conventions. - Used for derivatives, such as options and covered warrants to indicate a versioning of the contract when required due to corporate actions to the underlying. Should not be used to indicate type of option - use the CFICode[461] for this purpose.

name: SecurityExchange

name: IssueDate
elements.definition: The date on which a bond or stock offering is issued. It may or may not be the same as the effective date ("Dated Date") or the date on which interest begins to accrue ("Interest Accrual Date")(Note tag # was reserved in FIX 4.1, added in FIX 4.3)(prior to FIX 4.4 field was of type UTCDate) - Date instrument was issued. For Fixed Income IOIs for new issues, specifies the issue date.

name: CFICode
elements.definition: Indicates the type of security using ISO 10962 standard, Classification of Financial Instruments (CFI code) values. ISO 10962 is maintained by ANNA (Association of National Numbering Agencies) acting as Registration Authority. See "Appendix 6-B FIX Fields Based Upon Other Standards". See also the Product (460) and SecurityType (167) fields. It is recommended that CFICode be used instead of SecurityType (167) for non-Fixed Income instruments.A subset of possible values applicable to FIX usage are identified in "Appendix 6-D CFICode Usage - ISO 10962 Classification of Financial Instruments (CFI code)" - Indicates the type of security using ISO 10962 standard, Classification of Financial Instruments (CFI code) values. It is recommended that CFICode be used instead of SecurityType for non-Fixed Income instruments.

name: Warrant
definition: The entitlement category comprises financial instruments providing the holder with the privilege to subscribe to or receive specific assets on terms specified. Warrants are a group of financial instruments in the entitlement category, which permit the holder to purchase a specified amount of a financial instrument, commodity, currency or other during a specified period at a specified price. (Source: ISO 10962 -- Classification of Financial Instruments (CFI) code)

name: DatedDate
